topics.title: Hypergrowth essentials: product, virality, scaling leaders
topics.summary: Carilu opens with what drives true hypergrowth: an amazing product people love, organic/viral word-of-mouth that can’t be bought, and “riding the lightning” by hiring leaders who’ve seen the next stage of scale.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Carilu’s background advising hypergrowth B2B companies and leading marketing at Atlassian through IPO, plus what the episode will cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Rows.com and Braintrust, covering modern spreadsheets with integrations and a decentralized talent network for hiring contractors quickly.

topics.title: Habits to reach the C-suite
topics.summary: Carilu shares executive-track tradeoffs and the behaviors that accelerate advancement: working hard, learning deeply, taking on “white space” responsibilities, and building cross-functional experience early.

topics.title: No shortcuts: discipline, learning, and executive mindset
topics.summary: They discuss the reality of sustained effort, then Carilu outlines executive mental models: tie work to revenue, speak CEO/board language, learn finance, do tours of duty across functions, build relationships, and pick high-momentum companies.

topics.title: How to pick winning companies
topics.summary: Carilu explains how she evaluates “phenomenal” companies (rule of 40, investor quality, NPS, NDR, growth/burn, market leadership, Glassdoor) and shares personal decision heuristics from her Post-its (e.g., “Hell yes or no”).

topics.title: Career growth during downturns and layoffs
topics.summary: Advice for job seekers: endurance, don’t settle for bad logos, leverage networks, and follow profitable industries; for employed folks: downturns create “white space” to take on more responsibility even if title/salary lag temporarily.

topics.title: Non-digital brand advertising: when it works
topics.summary: Carilu shares lessons from spending hundreds of millions on awareness campaigns (Oracle, Atlassian): ads amplify product reality, require sustained consistency, and can be effective when narrowly targeted (e.g., Snowflake’s single billboard).

topics.title: What hypergrowth companies have in common
topics.summary: Using examples like Miro, 1Password, Productboard, and ChatGPT, Carilu highlights the core drivers: beloved products, organic inbound/viral sharing loops, and organizational ability to scale quickly by hiring ahead and using mentors/advisors.

topics.title: Beyond virality: consistency across growth levers
topics.summary: They address founders without obvious virality: Atlassian’s growth relied heavily on SEO/SEM and steady execution; hypergrowth is built through customer obsession and incremental improvements across channels, not a single magic bullet.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda, describing how teams centralize docs, data, and workflows, plus a startup credit offer.

topics.title: How to accelerate word of mouth
topics.summary: Carilu outlines three levers: empower internal thought leaders (founders/experts in forums), publish genuinely helpful content, and build customer communities (user groups/events) where happy customers sell to prospects.

topics.title: Atlassian’s PLG model and delayed sales hiring
topics.summary: Carilu explains Atlassian’s unique founder-controlled approach: minimal sales/marketing spend, heavy R&D investment, and sales focused on renewals/enterprise assistance rather than net-new prospecting; discussion covers when to add sales and PLG/sales hybrids.

topics.title: Making big growth strategy shifts cross-functionally
topics.summary: Carilu describes common growth levers (new products, segments, verticals, global, partners, upmarket) and why change fails when treated as a single-department issue; success requires CEO/C-suite alignment, resourcing, and coordinated product/marketing/sales/support moves.

topics.title: Why CEOs don’t trust CMOs (and firing risks)
topics.summary: Carilu explains trust gaps: CMOs must connect spend to revenue, forecast levers credibly, and speak CEO/board metrics; she also notes leadership fundamentals (team quality, operations, strategic market thinking) that determine CMO success.
